title: ERMAC Back In Action. Latest Version of Android Banking Trojan Targets over 400 Applications

meta.title: Latest Version of Android Banking Trojan Targets over 400 Applications

sentences.text: Cyble Research Labs came across a Twitter post wherein a researcher mentioned the distribution of ERMAC 2.0. ERMAC is an Android Banking Trojan that was first discovered in late August 2021, when it was found targeting Poland. ERMAC 1.0 was capable of stealing the credentials of 378 applications. The Threat Actor was renting it out for $3K/month on a cybercrime forum.
sentences.html: Cyble Research Labs came across a Twitter post wherein a researcher mentioned the distribution of ERMAC 2.0. ERMAC is an Android Banking Trojan that was first discovered in late August 2021, when it was found targeting Poland. ERMAC 1.0 was capable of stealing the credentials of 378 applications. The Threat Actor was renting it out for $3K/month on a cybercrime forum.

sentences.text: Recently, Cyble Research Labs observed that an upgraded version ERMAC 2.0 has been available on underground forums for rent at $5K/month and targets 467 applications for stealing credentials.
sentences.html: Recently, Cyble Research Labs observed that an upgraded version – ERMAC 2.0 – has been available on underground forums for rent at $5K/month and targets 467 applications for stealing credentials.

sentences.text: Figure 1 Cyber Crime Forum selling ERMAC 2.0

We have observed that the ERMAC 2.0 is being delivered through fake sites. For example, via the Bolt Food site a delivery platform that provides high-quality food delivery services. The fake app impersonates the Bolt Food Android application and targets Polish Bolt Food users.
sentences.html: We have observed that the ERMAC 2.0 is being delivered through fake sites. For example, via the Bolt Food site – a delivery platform that provides high-quality food delivery services. The fake app impersonates the Bolt Food Android application and targets Polish Bolt Food users.

sentences.text: Figure 2 Fake Bolt Food site distributing malware
Apart from the fake Bolt Food site, EMRAC 2.0 spreads through fake browser update sites, as shown in Figure 3.
sentences.html: Apart from the fake Bolt Food site, EMRAC 2.0 spreads through fake browser update sites, as shown in Figure 3.

sentences.text: Figure 3 Fake browser update site (Source MalwareHunterTeam)
The below image shows the Control Panel of ERMAC 2.0 Banking Trojan. In the UI, the Threat Actor (TA) has named it ERMVC PVNEL.
sentences.html: The below image shows the Control Panel of ERMAC 2.0 Banking Trojan. In the UI, the Threat Actor (TA) has named it “ERMVC PVNEL.”

sentences.text: Figure 4 Control Panel
App Name: Bolt Food<crlf>Package Name: com.kototomumeci.nacipiyi<crlf>SHA256 Hash: 2cc727c4249235f36bbc5024d5a5cb708c0f6d3659151afc5ae5d42d55212cb5
sentences.html:
• App Name: Bolt Food
  • Package Name: com.kototomumeci.nacipiyi  
  • SHA256 Hash: 2cc727c4249235f36bbc5024d5a5cb708c0f6d3659151afc5ae5d42d55212cb5

sentences.text: Figure 5 shows the metadata information of an application.
sentences.html: Figure 5 shows the metadata information of an application.

sentences.text: Figure 5 App Metadata Information
The malicious application asks for 43 permissions, of which the TA exploits 12. The malwares harmful permission requests are listed below:
sentences.html: The malicious application asks for 43 permissions, of which the TA exploits 12. The malware’s harmful permission requests are listed below:

1.1: Allows an application to request installing packages
1.2: Allows an application to initiate a phone call without going through the Dialer user interface for the user to confirm the call
1.3: Allows an application to receive SMS messages
1.4: Allows an application to read SMS messages
1.5: Allows an application to send SMS messages
1.6: Allows an application to read the user’s contacts data
1.7: Allows read access to the device’s phone number
1.8: Allows an app to create windows shown on top of all other apps.
1.9: Allows an application to read from external storage
1.10: Allows an application to record audio
1.11: Allows an application to write to external storage

sentences.text: Apart from the applications subclass, the rest of the components identified from the Manifest file are missing. We can thus infer that the application is packed.
sentences.html: Apart from the application’s subclass, the rest of the components identified from the Manifest file are missing. We can thus infer that the application is packed.

sentences.text: Figure 6 Manifest File
Upon execution, the malicious application unpacks the DEX file present in the assets folder and then loads the classes.
sentences.html: Upon execution, the malicious application unpacks the DEX file present in the assets folder and then loads the classes.

sentences.text: In this case, the dropped dex file name is pqiRsn.json, which has all the missing classes
sentences.html: In this case, the dropped dex file name is “pqiRsn.json,” which has all the missing classes

sentences.text: The strings present in the classes are encoded using base64 and encrypted using the AES-128-bit algorithm.
sentences.html: The strings present in the classes are encoded using base64 and encrypted using the AES-128-bit algorithm.

sentences.text: The Secret Key and IVparameter were dumped during dynamic analysis. Both Secret Key and IVparameter are used to decrypt hardcoded strings present in the file as well as encrypt the data sent to the C&C server. The below image explains the decryption process.
sentences.html: The Secret Key and IVparameter were dumped during dynamic analysis. Both Secret Key and IVparameter are used to decrypt hardcoded strings present in the file as well as encrypt the data sent to the C&C server. The below image explains the decryption process.

sentences.text: Figure 7 Encryption and Decryption Technique

On installing the application, it prompts the user to turn on the Accessibility Service. When the victim grants this permission, it starts abusing services by auto-enabling overlay activity and auto-granting permissions.
sentences.html: On installing the application, it prompts the user to turn on the Accessibility Service. When the victim grants this permission, it starts abusing services by auto-enabling overlay activity and auto-granting permissions.

sentences.text: Figure 8 Accessibility Service

After granting the Accessibility permission, the malware sends a list of installed applications on the victims Android device to the C&C server. The malware then downloads and installs the injection modules of targeted applications based on this application list.
sentences.html: After granting the Accessibility permission, the malware sends a list of installed applications on the victim’s Android device to the C&C server. The malware then downloads and installs the injection modules of targeted applications based on this application list.

sentences.text: Figure 9 showcases the C&C communications from the victims device, which sends the details of installed applications and receives a response, including a list of targeted applications to perform overlay activity. At the time of our analysis, it was observed that the Unocoin wallet was the targeted application by the attacker.
sentences.html: Figure 9 showcases the C&C communications from the victim’s device, which sends the details of installed applications and receives a response, including a list of targeted applications to perform overlay activity. At the time of our analysis, it was observed that the “Unocoin” wallet was the targeted application by the attacker.

sentences.text: Figure 9 Sending application list and receiving the response for the targeted app
The malware then receives an encrypted HTML phishing page, which will be decrypted and stored into the Shared Preference file named setting.xml with the action status, as shown in the figure below.
sentences.html: The malware then receives an encrypted HTML phishing page, which will be decrypted and stored into the Shared Preference file named “setting.xml” with the action status, as shown in the figure below.

sentences.text: Figure 10 Downloaded injection saved in Shared Preference file
As soon as the victim interacts with a targeted genuine application, the injected phishing page is displayed through setting.xml that can be used for credential harvesting.
sentences.html: As soon as the victim interacts with a targeted genuine application, the injected phishing page is displayed through setting.xml that can be used for credential harvesting.

sentences.text: Figure 11 shows the phishing page for Unocoin. The malware sends the start_inject command to the C&C server before sending the credentials.
sentences.html: Figure 11 shows the phishing page for “Unocoin.” The malware sends the start_inject command to the C&C server before sending the credentials.

sentences.text: Figure 11 Loading phishing page

The harvested credentials are sent to the same C&C server in the encrypted format, as shown in Figure 12. ERMAC 2.0 uses the command logs for code injection as well as data exfiltration functionalities.
sentences.html: The harvested credentials are sent to the same C&C server in the encrypted format, as shown in Figure 12. ERMAC 2.0 uses the command logs for code injection as well as data exfiltration functionalities.

sentences.text: Figure 12 Sending credentials to the C&C server
The TA can then use these credentials to steal cryptocurrency from the victims account.
sentences.html: The TA can then use these credentials to steal cryptocurrency from the victim’s account.

sentences.text: The below image shows the TAs phishing pages used to trick the victims into falling for a phishing scheme while attempting to access genuine applications.
sentences.html: The below image shows the TA’s phishing pages used to trick the victims into falling for a phishing scheme while attempting to access genuine applications.

sentences.text: Figure 13 Fake injected window targeting different applications
Cyble Research Labs witnessed that the malware has functionalities to target various banking applications of several banks worldwide.
sentences.html: Cyble Research Labs witnessed that the malware has functionalities to target various banking applications of several banks worldwide.

sentences.text: The commands used by ERMAC 2.0 to execute malicious operations are:
sentences.html: The commands used by ERMAC 2.0 to execute malicious operations are:

1.1: Sends the application list to download injections
1.2: Sends injection logs to the server
1.3: Check the application status and send it to the server
1.6: Used to receive the phishing HTML page

sentences.text: The Threat Actor behind ERMAC used the leaked code from a well-known malware variant named Cerberus and modified the code to sell the Android botnets in cybercrime forums. Interestingly, we observed that ERMAC 2.0 is distributed rapidly through various phishing sites, primarily targeting Polish users.
sentences.html: The Threat Actor behind ERMAC used the leaked code from a well-known malware variant named “Cerberus” and modified the code to sell the Android botnets in cybercrime forums. Interestingly, we observed that ERMAC 2.0 is distributed rapidly through various phishing sites, primarily targeting Polish users.

sentences.text: ERMAC 2.0 steals credentials from different crypto wallets and targets multiple banking applications worldwide. We foresee that the TA behind ERMAC 2.0 will continue to develop new versions with more targeted applications, new TTPs, and new delivery methods.
sentences.html: ERMAC 2.0 steals credentials from different crypto wallets and targets multiple banking applications worldwide. We foresee that the TA behind ERMAC 2.0 will continue to develop new versions with more targeted applications, new TTPs, and new delivery methods.

sentences.text: We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the best practices given below:
sentences.html: We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the best practices given below:

sentences.text: Download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store.<crlf>Use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs, laptops, and mobile devices.<crlf>Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible.<crlf>Enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile device where possible.<crlf>Be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone.<crlf>Ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices.<crlf>Be careful while enabling any permissions.<crlf>Keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated.
sentences.html:
• Download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store.
  • Use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs, laptops, and mobile devices.
  • Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible.
  • Enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile device where possible.
  • Be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone.
  • Ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices.
  • Be careful while enabling any permissions.
  • Keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated.

chapters.title: How to identify whether you are infected?

sentences.text: Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed on mobile devices.<crlf>Keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly.
sentences.html:
• Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed on mobile devices.
  • Keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly.

chapters.title: What to do when you are infected?

sentences.text: Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card as in some cases, the malware can re-enable the Mobile Data.<crlf>Perform a factory reset.<crlf>Remove the application in case a factory reset is not possible.<crlf>Take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset.
sentences.html:
• Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card – as in some cases, the malware can re-enable the Mobile Data.
  • Perform a factory reset.
  • Remove the application in case a factory reset is not possible.
  • Take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset.

chapters.title: What to do in case of any fraudulent transaction?

sentences.text: In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report it to the concerned bank.
sentences.html: • In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report it to the concerned bank.

chapters.title: What should banks do to protect their customers?

sentences.text: Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding themselves from malware attacks via telephone, SMS, or emails.
sentences.html: • Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding themselves from malware attacks via telephone, SMS, or emails.
